newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: U.N. says arms inspector erred in entering church.
newsitem.headline: U.N. says arms inspector erred in entering church.

text.p: A U.N. weapons inspector erred in entering a church and a monastery near Baghdad but did not carry out an inspection, a senior U.N. official said on Wednesday.
The official was responding to Iraqi charges that a U.N. arms inspection team had committed a "flagrant aggression" earlier by entering the buildings.

Gustavo Zlauvinen, political adviser to chief U.N. weapons inspector Rolf Ekeus, said the incident occurred when a team led by an official of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and including members of the U.N. special commission (UNSCOM) in charge of disarming Iraq approached a group of buildings to conduct an inspection.

The team leader had not known they included religious establishments. But when he saw they included a church and a monastery, he erred in accepting a priest's invitation to enter for a few minutes, Zlauvinen said. The other team members remained outside.

"We don't consider it as being an inspection but rather a visit. In any case, we consider it was a personal mistake to even just go into the church and monastery....and we apologise for the inconvenience we caused, if any," he added.
